results.llm_response:
The user’s 52‑year‑old male presents with fever, chills, and hematuria suggestive of a complicated urinary tract infection. In contrast, the retrieved case (ID 142444) involves a 71‑year‑old male who arrived with subjective fevers, generalized weakness, myalgia, and intractable hiccups, along with confusion likely due to hyponatremia and urosepsis. Both patients had fever and evidence of urinary tract involvement—urinalysis in the case showed leukocyte esterase and white blood cells (ID 142444). However, hematuria was not reported in the retrieved case.

Demographically, the patient in the query is younger (52 years) and male, whereas the case involves an older male (71 years). The case also includes additional comorbidities such as bladder cancer history, hypertension, peripheral artery disease, smoking, and alcohol use, none of which are mentioned for the queried patient. Outcomes differ: the retrieved patient improved after sepsis protocol and broad‑spectrum antibiotics, eventually being discharged with resolution of fever; the query does not provide outcome data.

Overall, while both scenarios involve febrile patients with urinary tract findings, the case presents a more complex clinical picture with older age, multiple comorbidities, and an atypical infectious etiology (RMSF) that was ultimately identified after extensive work‑up.

Title: Unconventional Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever Presentation From Kentucky: A Compelling Case Report and Literature Review

Patient: We present the case of a 71-year-old male who arrived at the emergency department with complaints of subjective fevers, generalized weakness with myalgia, and persistent hiccups over the last two days. Notably, upon arrival, the patient displayed increasing confusion and agitation. His medical history included bladder cancer in remission, hypertension, peripheral artery disease, a history of smoking, and moderate alcohol consumption.
During the physical examination, the patient exhibited tachycardia (heart rate: 110/min), tachypnea (respiratory rate: 20/min), elevated blood pressure (150/90 mmHg), and a high fever, peaking at 103.3°F. Additionally, he experienced intractable hiccups. Urinalysis revealed trace leukocyte esterase, 6-10 white blood cells, and trace bacteria. Initially, his sodium level was low (Na 124) but later improved with guideline-directed therapy, remaining at 127, as shown in Table . The patient also presented with elevated creatinine kinase (CK) levels, although the electrocardiogram did not reveal ischemic changes or findings suggestive of myocarditis. Chest x-ray results showed emphysematous changes, and a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis indicated diverticulosis as shown in Figures , . Additionally, in our case, it is worth noting that this is associated with mildly elevated liver function tests (LFTs), which adds to the complexity of the clinical presentation as shown in Table .
The patient's condition showed improvement following the initiation of the sepsis protocol for urinary tract infection or pneumonia, which included the administration of normal saline and IV ceftriaxone, as well as pending blood and urine cultures. results.title: An Unusual Case of Complicated Urinary Tract Infection: Emphysematous Cystitis
results.llm_response:
The user’s patient is a 52‑year‑old man with fever, chills and hematuria who is thought to have a complicated urinary tract infection. The retrieved case (ID 81533) describes a 77‑year‑old male with uncontrolled type II diabetes who presented with sudden gross hematuria, fever (100.6 °F), and altered mental status. Both patients had significant hematuria and were treated for a complicated UTI; the older patient’s infection was identified as emphysematous cystitis caused by *E. coli*.

Key similarities include the presence of fever, hematuria, and the need for broad‑spectrum antibiotics followed by de‑escalation to ceftriaxone once cultures returned. Both patients were discharged with a Foley catheter and outpatient follow‑up, and both showed clinical improvement during hospitalization. The main differences are demographic: the case patient is older (77 vs 52), has uncontrolled diabetes and benign prostatic hyperplasia, and experienced delirium, whereas the user’s query does not mention these comorbidities or neuropsychiatric symptoms.
results.content:
Title: An Unusual Case of Complicated Urinary Tract Infection: Emphysematous Cystitis

Patient: A 77-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type II presented to our hospital with sudden onset hematuria and altered mental status. He was in his usual state of health, until about a week before the hospital presentation when he began to have generalized body fatigue. Symptoms developed into supra-pubic discomfort associated with frequency, urgency, dysuria, and gross hematuria involving the passage of clots. A day before the hospital visit, he was alert, oriented, and able to converse normally, but on the day of admission, he had been delirious and agitated for few hours. A review of systems was negative for weight changes, history of malignancy, urolithiasis, exposure to industrial chemicals, history of gastrointestinal tract disease, radiation therapy, and trauma.
Past medical histories were significant for coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He had had coronary artery bypass surgery, a total metatarsal amputation due to chronic recurrent osteomyelitis, and angioplasty with stent placement in the lower extremity. There was no known drug allergy and home medications were atorvastatin, clopidogrel, metoprolol succinate, glargine, liraglutide, losartan, tamsulosin, famotidine. He resided in a house, had a 35 pack-year cigarette smoking, drank alcohol occasionally, and denied recreational drug use. Family history was significant for diabetes mellitus II, ischemic stroke, and transient ischemic attack.
On examination, the patient’s temperature was 100.6°C, his heart rate was 90 beats per minute, blood pressure 143/94 mm Hg, respiratory rate 18 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. results.title: Renal abscess complicating acute pyelonephritis in children: Two cases report and literature review
results.llm_response:
The user’s patient is a 52‑year‑old man who presents with fever, chills and hematuria, suggestive of a complicated urinary tract infection. In contrast, the retrieved case (ID 142045) describes a 4‑year‑old boy who had fever, abdominal pain and hematuria but no reported chills or urinary urgency. Both patients exhibited elevated white blood cell counts and inflammatory markers, and both had evidence of renal involvement on imaging.

Demographically, the two cases differ markedly: one is an adult male, the other a young child. Clinically, the adult’s presentation includes systemic symptoms such as chills that were not noted in the pediatric case. The pediatric patient developed a bilateral renal abscess that recurred after initial treatment and required prolonged antibiotic therapy and further imaging to identify vesicoureteral reflux; no similar recurrence or anatomical abnormality is reported for the adult case. Outcomes also diverge: the child ultimately achieved resolution after multiple courses of antibiotics, whereas the adult’s outcome is not described in the retrieved text.
results.content:
Title: Renal abscess complicating acute pyelonephritis in children: Two cases report and literature review

Patient: A 4-year-old boy presented to Xiamen Children’s Hospital with fever and abdominal pain for 2 days on July 30, 2021. Fever occurred 2 days ago, with a peak of 39.0°C. Paroxysmal abdominal pain, vomiting once, with no diarrhea, no frequent urination, urgency, pain, hematuria, and foam urine were also reported. Routine blood tests showed WBC 14.65 × 109/L, NEU 11.85 × 109/L, CRP 246.7 mg/L, and the colored Doppler ultrasound of gastrointestinal tract was normal. The patient had a history of urinary tract infection (UTI) at the age of 1 year and 6 months. Physical examination showed body temperature to be 39.0°C, with stable vital signs. He complained of abdominal distention with tenderness, and no rebound pain. In-hospital laboratory evaluation showed leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers (WBC 12.47 × 109/L, NEU 9.80 × 109/L, CRP 202.43 mg/L; procalcitonin 16.81 μg/L; ESR 74 mm/hr) (Fig. A and B). Urine routine showed a pathological cast + μL, occult blood 3 + mg/L, red blood cells 3–5/HP, white blood cells 5–10/HP, and protein 2+. The routine, biochemical, ESR, tumor markers, anti-O, humoral immunity, and T cell subsets were all normal. Moreover, microbiological tests, like blood, urine, and fecal cultures, G test, GM test, T-Spot, were all negative. Urinary color Doppler ultrasound indicated diffuse damage of both kidney and nephritis was suspected, with a slightly thickened bladder wall.
After admission, bacterial infection was considered due to significantly elevated inflammatory markers. Ceftriaxone (80 mg/kg/d 7.30–7.31) was given intravenously, but the symptoms did not improve. After reexamination, the inflammatory index was higher than before. results.title: A Unique Presentation of an Infected Renal Cyst: A Case Report and Literature Review
results.llm_response:
The user’s 52‑year‑old male presents with fever, chills, and hematuria suggestive of a complicated urinary tract infection. In the retrieved case (ID 141712), the patient is older—60 years—and also reports fever, chills, and dark urine with hematuria, but his initial vital signs were afebrile and he had no abdominal or costovertebral tenderness at first presentation. Both patients share a history of urinary symptoms that prompted evaluation for infection.

In terms of clinical course, the case patient’s infection progressed despite empiric trimethoprim‑sulfamethoxazole, eventually requiring broad‑spectrum antibiotics and drainage of an infected renal cyst. The user’s query does not mention any underlying structural abnormality such as a cyst; instead it focuses on a presumed uncomplicated urinary tract infection that may become complicated. Thus, while both scenarios involve fever, chills, and hematuria, the retrieved case adds complexity with a renal cyst and a more prolonged febrile illness that required invasive intervention, whereas the user’s presentation appears to be an initial UTI without documented structural disease.

Title: A Unique Presentation of an Infected Renal Cyst: A Case Report and Literature Review

Patient: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department (ED) for worsening nausea and abdominal pain. Past medical history was significant for tobacco dependence, coronary artery disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), sialadenitis, stable renal cyst, and obesity. The patient also had a history of a chronic urethral stricture that required intermittent self-catheterization, most recently three weeks before presentation. He denied any previous history of a urinary tract infection (UTI). One week before the presentation, he developed pain in the lower abdomen at the end of urination, dark urine with “chunks,” and chills. The evaluation revealed a normal set of vital signs without a fever, a physical exam with lack of abdominal and costovertebral (CVA) tenderness, a urine analysis with pyuria and hematuria, and neutrophilic leukocytosis. Suspicion at that time was that the patient had a UTI. He was started on a planned 14-day course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). No urine culture was collected.
After starting TMP-SMX, he noted initial improvement; however, after a few days, he developed persistent chills with rigors but did not measure his temperature. The patient eventually presented to the ED for acute onset of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and bilateral lower back pain. He denied flank pain and urinary symptoms, such as dysuria and frequency. On presentation, he had sinus tachycardia (heart rate 122) but was otherwise afebrile (37°C) and hemodynamically stable. The physical exam again showed periumbilical abdominal tenderness and negative CVA tenderness bilaterally. The initial workup displayed a normal white blood cell (WBC) count and elevated creatinine level. C-reactive protein (CRP) was significantly elevated at 212.4 mg/L. results.title: Anuria, an Atypical Presentation of Leptospirosis: A Case Report
results.llm_response:
The user’s patient is a 52‑year‑old male with fever, chills and hematuria who is suspected of having a complicated urinary tract infection. The retrieved case (ID 105637) describes a 56‑year‑old female who presented with fever, chills, backache and polyarthralgia, along with jaundice and dark urine that progressed to anuria. Both patients share the symptom of fever and chills, but the retrieved patient’s presentation is more systemic and includes significant hepatic involvement (icterus, elevated bilirubin) rather than hematuria.

In terms of demographics, the ages are similar (52 vs 56 years), though the genders differ (male vs female). The clinical course in the retrieved case involved severe renal failure requiring haemodialysis for several weeks, whereas the user’s query does not mention such complications. Outcomes also diverge: the female patient eventually recovered normal kidney function after months of dialysis, while no outcome data are provided for the male patient with a suspected urinary tract infection.
results.content:
Title: Anuria, an Atypical Presentation of Leptospirosis: A Case Report

Patient: A 56-year-old female from western Terai presented to our emergency department in September with a history of fever for five days, the maximum temperature documented 102° Fahrenheit, associated with chills, rigor, backache and polyarthralgia. She also complained of progressive yellowish discoloration of eyes, darkening of the colour of urine and mild to moderate abdominal pain on the right upper quadrant region. It was not associated with itching or clay coloured stool. Her urine output decreased amounting to oliguria, three days after the onset of fever which then progressed to anuria in the following days.
She did not have a history of use of Non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or alternative medicines, prior history of nausea, vomiting, loose motions, neck stiffness or altered mental status.
On her initial presentation, she was ill-looking and had pallor as well as icterus. There were no signs of clubbing or lymphadenopathy. She had a firm, tender liver measuring three centimetres below the right subcostal margin in the midclavicular line. There was no splenomegaly. The rest of the systemic examinations were unremarkable.
Her laboratory parameters at the time of admission are given below. Her liver function test showed conjugated hyperbilirubinemia ().
She tested negative for Leptospira IgM antibody test initially. However, we tested her again for the Leptospira IgM antibody owing to a strong clinical suspicion. She tested positive on the repeat test that was done ten days after the onset of illness. Based on the initial negative report of leptospirosis, she was treated primarily with a suspicion of sepsis but the etiological diagnosis was obscure. She tested negative for Malaria, leishmaniasis, scrub typhus, and brucella.

results.title: Renal disease masquerading as pyrexia of unknown origin
results.llm_response:
The user’s 52‑year‑old male presents with fever, chills and hematuria suggestive of a complicated urinary tract infection. In contrast, the retrieved case (ID 167216) involves a 57‑year‑old gentleman who had high‑grade intermittent fever and chills for three months but no urinary symptoms or hematuria; his urine was essentially bland. Both patients share a prolonged febrile illness with chills, yet the user’s case includes hematuria while the retrieved case does not.

Demographically, the ages are similar (52 vs 57 years) and both are male. The retrieved patient had a history of type 2 diabetes and normal blood pressure, whereas no such comorbidities are mentioned for the user’s patient. Outcomes differ markedly: the retrieved case required extensive investigation, renal biopsy, steroid therapy, and eventually mycophenolate mofetil to control fever and improve kidney function, whereas the user’s query does not provide any treatment or outcome information.

Thus, while both cases involve persistent fever and chills in middle‑aged men, the presence of hematuria, absence of urinary findings in the retrieved case, and the extensive diagnostic workup and immunosuppressive therapy in ID 167216 set it apart from the user’s more typical presentation of a complicated urinary tract infection.
results.content:
Title: Renal disease masquerading as pyrexia of unknown origin

Patient: A 57-year-old gentleman was referred with high grade intermittent fever with chills since 3 months. He was a longstanding type 2 diabetic, on oral hypoglycemic agents with a fairly good sugar control. He did not have any constitutional symptoms like weight loss or anorexia. He was normotensive and had no specific urinary symptoms. Other than the fever for which he consumed paracetamol, he was fairly asymptomatic. There were no clinical clues to the etiology for the fever on systemic examination.
The complete blood count of the patient showed an Hemoglobin 11 g/dL, total leukocyte count 10,100 (polymorphs 85, lymphocytes 13% and eosinophils 2%) and a normal platelet count of 2.73 lacs. Liver function tests were essentially normal with a bilirubin of 0.7 mg/dL, alanine aminotransferase/ALT of 36 and 31 IU/L, serum albumin 3.84 g/dL, and serum globulin 2.46 g/dL. Renal function tests showed BUN 55 mg/dL, serum creatinine 1.5 mg/dL, and normal serum electrolytes. The urine analysis was essentially bland with no albumin, 1-2 pus cells, and no red cells.
Test results during these 3 months revealed an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 90 mm at the end of 1 h and two high C-reactive protein levels of 35.8, 24, and 18.5 mg/L (Normal up to 6 mg/L). Complete blood count, urine examination, chest radiology, and 2D Echo performed to investigate the cause of the fever were all normal. Blood and urine cultures were also negative. Serum Ferritin and complement levels were normal. anti-nuclear antibodies and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody were negative. angiotensin converting enzyme levels were normal. Tumor marker profile was negative. Enzyme immunoassays for tuberculosis and brucellosis were negative. He was treated empirically with antibiotics during this period with no permanent relief.
